column4: I'm writing a script that prompts the user for many things on a CLI install of Ubuntu. I'm considering switching from dialog to zenity. Is it practical to start a basic xterm so zenity can function on a CLI machine?
I read recently that it's generally frowned upon to run an xserver on a server
'nite StepNjump
It's a CLI install of Ubuntu for space reasons, but it's not a server machine. dialog's file select prompt is a little non-user-friendly
then it sounds like a good idea to me :)
What would I need to just get zenity working from the CLI? (xterm?)
I've never done it but I'd assume not much more than the xserver & ssh
(or xterm if you're at the machine)
xserver and xterm?
& gtk
Cipzzz: I have xterm running but it's in the upper left corner of the screen, not fullscreen
Chipzzz*
are you at the machine with the x-server or remote?
at the machine. Running startx opens what I believe is xterm. Running xterm directly results in ""Can't open display" though
what happens when the window is open & you type "xeyes"?
it works, the eyes are in the upper left corner though
you can't move the window (or is there no window)?
No window, it's just a black screen with a prompt in the upper left corner, but the 'window' appears to only take up maybe 1/4 of the screen in the upper left corner
try this... go back to the terminal & type "export DISPLAY=:0.0", then start your xsession
Same thing, Though I suppose it's not a major issue since zenity appears normally above the terminal, with no window borders though
you might look into Xnest... I think it only needs an xserver to run
If I try to start zenity from CLI, I get 'cannot open display :0.0', I'm assuming because there is no xserver running?
you would have to start the xserver first
